Notes: facial components such as nose wrinkles or eye opening elicit systematic confusion while decoding facial expressions of disgust and anger and fear and surprise, respectively, suggesting that other co-occurring signals contribute to their interpretation.

In spontaneous emotional displays of athletes, the body – and not the face – better predicts participants’ correct assessments of victory and loss pictures, as conveying positive or negative emotions (Aviezer et al., 2012), suggesting at least that face and body make different contributions to interpretations of the displays.

emotional displays are compositional - that each signal component, or possibly specific clusters of components (Du et al., 2014), may have their own interpretations, and make a contribution to the complex meaning of the whole.
different combinations of body and face features can modulate emotion recognition and judgments of win and loss
theory of compositionality in the expression and interpretation of emotions.
